Despite your great fear of the light, the sheer bliss of the struggling girl in your stomach overrides all else, so that before you have time to worry, you’re headed to the surface, to hunt for more prey.

The violent struggles in your stomach slow down to a steady hum. She was great while she lasted, but those mermaids expire quick once they hit the tummy. The large lump in your stomach slowly reconfigures, moving partially down into your intestines. Without the comforting vibrations from your belly, you suddenly feel skittish about confronting the light. Still wanting another meal, you dart over to a rocky outcropping that’s barely visibly behind the murky dark water it hides from the sun.

You follow the cliff up for about an hour, until the water ends about 100 feet above you. It’s mind-blowing, really. You never knew the water ended. A small part of you wants to adventure beyond your aquatic home, but the cliff, and with it the consolation of darkness, ends here. Besides, something tells you that outside the water lies danger. Seeing as you’re pretty much top of the food chain, and don’t keep in touch with that instinct much, you feel it’s a wise idea to listen to it.

So you wait.

And wait.

After a while, some partially digested bones float to the surface above you.

And then you wait.

After a while, you forget exactly what you were waiting for. Goblin sharks are clever, but overall, not the smartest fish in the sea.

Regardless, you wait.

Finally, hearing a voice in the distance, you retreat further into the bleak water, until you’re parallel with the sheer stone wall. The voice is getting louder. It’s low and booming, yet inherently feminine. As it draws closer, you can make out another sound, higher pitched, and definitely belonging to a creature of the female sex. They both emerge from the peak of the cliff, and you remember why you were waiting all this time: Fresh meat.

One of the mermaids is the about the same size as your last meal, about 18 inches longer, making her 3½ feet total, and sized conveniently to fill your stomach. Her short purple hair is tied into a bun using seaweed, and her cheerful blue eyes and her flat chest reveal her young age.

The other was a giantess mermaid, a mermonster to some, but a mermeal to you all the same. Ignoring the fact that she’s about twice your length and almost as wide as you, the other problem in downing her would be those firm, circular breasts. But oh, the reward you receive once she was yours. You nibble on a piece of her long, trailing, scarlet hair and savor the flavor. You could just tug on her hair and bring her down to your level… but it’s too late now. The mermaids continue lazily swimming and chatting, heading away from you now, giving you a strategic opportunity to attack, as well as a nice view of their rounded hindquarters.

The two mermaids are laughing, which is the only universally understood language underwater. Fish laugh, believe it or not. Lobsters and crabs kinda do. Even sharks make a low grunt akin to cruel laughter as they sneak up behind a school of unsuspecting mermaids. Which is unfortunate, really, because it allows the mermaids to see the shark tailing them, which in this case, is you.

You still have a second to attack. You charge forward, aiming for the larger one, but as you angle yourself upwards, a small, terribly bright orb becomes visible from beyond the water’s end, blinding you. Undeterred, you swim in the direction you had been going previously. You feel soft, creamy skin and salty, hard scales collide with your palate and your jaws instinctively clamp down on the chewy flesh. Both mermaids scream, creating a cacophonous chorus that’s cut short as suddenly, there’s no more water.

Even through your scaly eyelids, the horrid light grows brighter. It’s impossible to breathe up here, and it seems as if you’ll be stuck here forever.Fortunately, your belly collides with the water (and the other mermaid) before long. Your lustful hunger overriding any curiosity concerning what the hell just happened, you continue into the dark abyss, screams of agony dimming behind you.

Slowly, your vision returns as you grow accustomed to the steadily growing darkness. Crying silently in your maw, you can now view your prized catch…

“Damn!”, you think, in the fish equivalent to cursing. There’s no way you’ll catch up to her now. Her arm is perfectly fine now, it was all a ruse.

Regardless of the impossibility of catching up to her, you swim with all your might in the direction she took off in. This is where your electro-sensitivity really comes into play. Within seconds, you’ve located her, and you’re surprised when you catch up to her in less than a minute.

Not being one to give up so quickly after so much work, you latch onto her tail fin and begin swallowing it up. Scales are not the reason anybody eats mermaids, but they don’t taste half bad. Once you lick them clean of the salty residue (and, on dirty mermaids, the occasional barnacle), they prove to be quite sweet. To your surprise, the tail is quite flexible and folds up quite nicely into your waiting stomach. You manage to work your way up to the fringe of the scales, where her skin begins. With an enormous shove and grunt audible even from within the sand, she pushes free, revealing her slime-coated face. It’s thick, oily stuff, and it doesn’t seem like it’s going to be washed off by salt water any time soon.
Regardless, the blinded mermaid takes off in a random direction, waving her tail – the one that’s still in your stomach – frantically. She’s even worse than she was before – blinded from both goo and darkness, and her nimble, elegant tail replaced by your bloated body. 143111122.content:
You suddenly have a Goblin Shark epiphany. Using your trademark tongue, you lasso her loose strands into a sort of hairstyle (like the smaller mermaid from earlier had) and swallow it down your gullet. It’s really long hair – you can feel some of it snaking through your intestines already. Swallowing it greedily, the tension causes the behemoth’s upper torso to arch back. You could put a swordfish nose-first against her back, pull her hair back, and make a bow out of her. You plan on making other, more nutritious things out of her.

Even in this backbreaking position, the giantess endures and swims onward. You’re able to use her hair to steer her clear of any dangers. A Mermaid, it seems, although very human in nature, is only as smart as a horse

Your stomach gurgles as it works on her thick scales. This churning is shortly accompanied by a painful moan from the mermaid, which shortly crescendos into a low, bellowing scream that could give a blue whale a run for its money.

You feel her tail falling apart in your stomach. The mermaid stops swimming now, and begins writhing as the two of you slowly sink back to the ocean floor. Even once you reach rock bottom, she’s still clawing at the ground, dragging you yard by yard across the ground. After about an hour, what’s left of her beautiful tail has become mushy enough, and even before it’s all arrived in the intestines, you’re swallowing down her skin.

THIS is why people eat mermaids. Not that you’re an expert, this is only your second taste. But the skin is so smooth and creamy, unlike anything else found underwater. It also goes down nicely, and something about the softness of it just begs to be felt by the esophagus. And you note that, for the record, the ass was every bit as delicious as you had previously imagined.

You manage to swallow up to her to her mounds, which now wait inside your maw. Skin won’t take too long to digest, but you still have free time, which you spend manipulating her candy with your tongue. This intrusion stimulates her to one final assault, which involves massaging your stomach with her free hands. Well, she’s actually hitting you with them, but it still feels great. Watching your stomach jiggle entertains you as much as jiggling her yourself does, and little does she know she’s actually speeding up the digestion process.

It’s not so funny when she picks up some rocks and does the same thing. It’s not anything major, but she’s covered your entire body in marks. Your skin is thick and recovers before much (or any) blood is shed, but she’s covering your body in small freckled pocks of pain, and it won’t scab over nicely. You start to wish she’d just bleed to death already, but since all her blood drains into your bloated belly, that won’t happen for a while.

At long last, as you digest her innards and lungs, the not-so-gentle giant lay still, forever. The rest is easy. You manage to swallow her shoulders with a little munching and compressing. Both of her arms are sucked in, leaving only her head.

Before you finish her, you lick her face clean of the slime that had covered it all this time. It tasted awful, and you quickly cleansed your pallet with her cheeks, still rosy with fear and fury. Once she was cleaned, her terrified face, frozen for all time, was revealed. Her eyes were wide open, seeming to scream for help, while her mouth was locked in silent prayer. A few final bubbles escaped from her eyes and lazily made their way all the way up to the surface.



You were well fed for a month. So well-fed, you couldn’t move. Nothing dared touch you, you were enormous, By the time the nutrients and fats had all been arranged, you were easily three times your previous size. In the meantime, while she digested, you used her leftover hairs as tripwires. Whenever something out in the darkness was caught in one, or started nibbling on it, you reeled them in. Each time, you hoped for another lost mermaid, but was disappointed.
60 days after your first mermeal, you decide it’s time to go on the prowl again. With your new girth, you can eat small mermaids like krill or popcorn. They still taste the same, but why not challenge yourself more? You’ve heard humans are tasty, and although you’ve never seen one, your good shark buddies have said that they’re all skin and no scales.
